Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Testing the relationship between nasal traits and the anterior dentition in Homo

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
While the mid-face (the nose and the region around it) is argued to be an aspect of anatomy that is highly constrained by the need to function in respiration, there are obvious differences in mid-facial form between both fossil human species and populations of living humans. The cause of this variation is still not entirely understood. One nasal trait in particular, a distinctly depressed shape to the bottom of the inside of the nose (the internal nasal floor), has previously been argued to be a Neanderthal adaptation to cold climates to help warm inhaled air. Recent research, however, has cast this into doubt. The bones which makes up the majority of the nasal capsule, the paired maxillae, also house the upper dentition and must respond to the competing biological constraints that respiration and mastication place on them. Pilot data for this project indicate that the development of the front teeth during childhood may be the ultimate cause for shape differences in the internal nasal floor. This project by doctoral student Christina Nicholas (University of Iowa), under the supervision of Dr. Robert Franciscus, tests the hypothesis that aspects of the shape of the internal nose, such as internal nasal floor depression versus the lack of depression, are correlated with variation in anterior dental traits. If so, this may imply that some internal nasal traits are a secondary result of evolutionary factors acting upon anterior dental traits (e.g., tooth root size, and timing of tooth eruption). A sample of CT scans of recent humans and 3D surface scans of fossil humans will be analyzed to examine the relationship between internal nasal traits and anterior dental traits.

This research project takes a developmental perspective to investigating mid-facial evolution, with a sample composed of individuals from birth through young adulthood. Little is currently known about the development of internal nasal floor shape, despite the fact that the internal nasal floor plays an important role in pediatric facial surgeries such as the realignment of deviated nasal septa. The results of this project thus have clear relevance not only for biological anthropology, but also clinical areas such as pediatric maxillo-facial surgery and orthodontia. This project also will contribute to training a female scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study investigated aspects of midfacial growth in humans and other members of our genus (Homo) in order to test hypotheses about the evolution of midfacial form using geometric morphometrics (a methodology which analyzes morphological shape, size, and their possible interrelationship), dental measurements, and dental development estimation. The sample in this study consisted of CT scans of living humans (n=110) and crania from skeletal collections (n=33), as well as 3D laser scans of fossil crania (n=47) and crania from skeletal collections (n=86). Our findings indicate that changes in internal nasal anatomy, specifically nasal floor shape, during growth are not related to facial or mid-facial size, including anterior tooth root lengths, but instead appear to arise due to differences in the timing of tooth eruption. Children who erupt their teeth early are more likely to develop a particular nasal floor shape, typically referred to as a ‘depressed’ nasal floor. The implications of our findings are relevant for both paleoanthropology and to clinical fields. Firstly, Neandertals have a very high occurrence of nasal floor depression, and previous research had failed to identify why this might be. Our research suggests that Neandertals—and some modern humans—may develop depressed nasal floors because of their slightly earlier tooth development, although it still remains unclear why other premodern (archaic) groups, unlike the Neandertals, do not show a similar high occurrence of nasal floor depression since they are either documented or assumed to show earlier tooth development compared to living modern humans as well. Among living humans, the association of nasal floor depression with precocious dental development is important due to the fact that the nasal floor configuration was previously assumed to maintain a stable spatial relationship with the rest of the structures of the nose during post-natal growth. Previous research had indicated that the adult shape of many facial traits is established during prenatal development.  In our prior work, we had identified the fact that in some children, this is not the case. Clinical procedures, such as nasal septoplasty (the surgical correction of a deviated nasal septum), rely upon that now questionable assumption that the spatial relationship is static after birth. Our results indicate that, with further research, we may now be able to predict which children might undergo postnatal changes in this relationship and which might not, allowing surgeons to better assess when to perform such procedures on young children.
